Award.AwardTitle: An Establishment-Level View of the Great Depression

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Great Depression was the most serious economic crisis in American history and so has attracted great interest from economists. For good or bad, the Depression serves as a litmus test for numerous economic policy debates. For this reason, any contribution to our understanding of this period strengthens the quality of debate surrounding these issues and will lead to better policy. Almost all existing studies of the Depression have relied on aggregate data, leaving economists with an incomplete understanding of the decline and recovery.
The goal of this project is collect two comprehensive sets of micro-level observations from the Great Depression. The first source is the Census of Manufactures taken in 1929, 1931, 1933, and 1935. The comprehensive sample, which would be released publicly, would combine a newly collected set of industries with previously collected data on particular states and industries. In total, the sample proposed here will comprise more than 10% of the extant schedules. A limitation of the Census records is a lack of information on the financial position of the establishments or their parent companies. Our second source of data is the records of Dun & Bradstreet (D&B), a major credit rating agency at the time, which fills that gap. In particular, this source provides a measure of creditworthiness, similar to modern credit ratings, and an estimate of the establishment's net worth. The end product of this project will be a true public good serving as a central resource for economic historians and macroeconomists studying the Depression.

We then plan to answer some simple though crucial questions regarding the declines in key macro aggregates, including employment and the price level. We also will link the owners of the establishments to the population censuses of 1920 and 1930 to obtain demographic information. This will allow us to study, particularly for small business owners, what characteristics of the owners themselves helped predict survival. This will offer insights into the role of credit constraints in the Depression. Finally, we will use the ability to link the establishments into their parent companies to study the role of "markets" for resources inside of the firm. In particular, we will address whether they can act as a substitute for the malfunctioning external capital markets at the time. For these last two projects, the D&B records will be crucial in providing information on the dependence of businesses on external credit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to collect a dataset of manufacturing establishments from the Census of Manufactures in 1929, 1931, 1933, and 1935, the first half of the Great Depression. This dataset, covering over 25 industries, provides a fascinating glimpse of manufacturing establishment behavior during the most severe downturn in American economic history. It contains information about income and hours worked, products produced and materials consumed, and other variables of wide economic interest. We also linked these establishments together across time, and linked individual manufacturing plants into firms. These links, constructed through identifying information such as names and addresses of firms, allow us to study the internal dynamics of multi-plant firms and to better understand the evolution of individual establishments through the Depression. This dataset, which will be made freely available, will provide an indispensable resource for economists, historians, and policy makers interested in understanding the Depression.

We have used these data so far to answer a number of questions. Many scholars including the fomer chairmen of the Federal Reserve Ben Bernanke  have pointed to the role of the financial crisis in deepening and lengthening the Depression through declines in investment. One piece of our work from these data shows that the banking crisis might have broader effects extending to the allocation of resources across establishments and thereby overall productivity. Another paper examines the role of firm networks in "spreading" local shocks to economic conditions across the country. In many cases, firms own many establishments that are distributed across the country. These establishments might be subject to different local conditions and, in principle, firms could respond to these differences in conditions across their establishments by reallocating resources. These networks could potentially be more important in a period in which the financial system underwent widespread collapse. We find evidence for this cross-region reallocation of resources, with establishments that are part of a multi-establishment firm more sensitive to local fluctuations.  So rather than operating as a risk-sharing mechanism, firms ampllify the effects of these local shocks. This finding has important implications for the geographic distribution of the Depression and why so many different parts of the country experienced the Depression in the same way.

In a third paper, we have documented changes in the earnings distribution over this time period. The Census allows us to not only look at average earnings by establishment, but also to go further and classify workers into white and blue collar jobs. This allows us to study changes in the returns to skill. We find that this skill premium increases from 1929 to 1933 before falling back in 1935. Within blue and white collar jobs, the dispersion in earnings increases between 1929 and 1933 and 1935. We think these results help to inform our understanding of the secular decline in the returns to skill starting in 1929 and extending through the 1970s, the so-called Great Compression. With the sharp increase in the returns to skill since then and the overall increase in income inequality staring in the 1980s, understanding the dynamics of the income distribution has become more important than ever.
